intro: Tetracarpum wrightii, commonly known as Wright's four-fruit plant, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its hairy stems and showy, five-petaled flowers that bloom in late spring. Its fruit is a capsule that splits open to release seeds, a feature typical of the genus Tetracarpum. It thrives in rocky soils and is often found in desert or semi-arid environments.
